Line 295: Line 295:
During the night of 5â6 February, some protesters continued to camp out in Tahrir Square, and Alexandria had peaceful late-night protests. However, [[gunshot|gunfire]] was heard in the early hours of the day in Cairo.<ref name="aljazlive"/>
During the night of 5â6 February, some protesters continued to camp out in Tahrir Square, and Alexandria had peaceful late-night protests. However, [[gunshot|gunfire]] was heard in the early hours of the day in Cairo.<ref name="aljazlive"/>
â
Egyptian Christians held mass in Tahrir Square in Cairo in order to counter claims by state television that most of the anti-Mubarak protesters are members of the Muslim Brotherhood. Copts wanted to show that they are a part of Egypt's popular uprising and share the same grievances as the rest of the country. Christians started their Sunday Mass in Cairo's Tahrir Square as Muslim protesters formed a ring around them to protect them during the service.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.onislam.net/english/news/africa/450890-egypt-christians-muslims-unite-in-tahrir.html|title=Egypt Christians, Muslims Unite in Tahrir|publisher=On Islam|accessdate=06 February 2011}}</ref> Muslims later participated in ''[[Salat al-Janazah]]'' ({{lang-ar|'''ØµÙØ§Ø© Ø§ÙØ¬ÙØ§Ø²Ø©'''}}) (literally: funeral prayer).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gulf-times.com/site/topics/article.asp?cu_no=2&item_no=414062&version=1&template_id=37&parent_id=17|title=Prayers, tears for âmartyrsâ|publisher=Gulf Times|accessdate=06 February 2011}}</ref> Protesters in Cairo numbered in the vicinity of 1 million.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201126131743308918.html |title=Muslim Brotherhood in Egypt talks - Middle East |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date= |accessdate=2011-02-06}}</ref> <!--notable or WP:TRIVIA-->In the midst of all of this, a young couple decided to get married. They planned to spend their honeymoon in Tahrir Square.<ref>{{cite web|url=In Egypt, a wedding amid the protests: 'Life shouldn't stop'|title=BBC News - Egypt unrest |publisher=Washington Post|date=2011-02-07|accessdate=2011-02-08}}</ref>
+
Egyptian Christians held mass in Tahrir Square in Cairo in order to counter claims by state television that most of the anti-Mubarak protesters are members of the Muslim Brotherhood. Copts wanted to show that they are a part of Egypt's popular uprising and share the same grievances as the rest of the country. Christians started their Sunday Mass in Cairo's Tahrir Square as Muslim protesters formed a ring around them to protect them during the service.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.onislam.net/english/news/africa/450890-egypt-christians-muslims-unite-in-tahrir.html|title=Egypt Christians, Muslims Unite in Tahrir|publisher=On Islam|accessdate=06 February 2011}}</ref> In a sign of unity, crowds in Tahrir Square are chanting "We are one, we are one" ahead of the prayers to be held at noon for those killed over the past 13 days of protest<ref name="aljazlive"/>. Muslims later participated in ''[[Salat al-Janazah]]'' ({{lang-ar|'''ØµÙØ§Ø© Ø§ÙØ¬ÙØ§Ø²Ø©'''}}) (literally: funeral prayer).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gulf-times.com/site/topics/article.asp?cu_no=2&item_no=414062&version=1&template_id=37&parent_id=17|title=Prayers, tears for âmartyrsâ|publisher=Gulf Times|accessdate=06 February 2011}}</ref> Protesters in Cairo numbered in the vicinity of 1 million.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201126131743308918.html |title=Muslim Brotherhood in Egypt talks - Middle East |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date= |accessdate=2011-02-06}}</ref> <!--notable or WP:TRIVIA-->In the midst of all of this, a young couple decided to get married. They planned to spend their honeymoon in Tahrir Square.<ref>{{cite web|url=In Egypt, a wedding amid the protests: 'Life shouldn't stop'|title=BBC News - Egypt unrest |publisher=Washington Post|date=2011-02-07|accessdate=2011-02-08}}</ref>
There were also demonstrations continuing in Alexandria focuses around the central train stations.{{Which?|date=February 2011}}<ref name="aljazlive"/>
There were also demonstrations continuing in Alexandria focuses around the central train stations.{{Which?|date=February 2011}}<ref name="aljazlive"/>
Line 301: Line 301:
Journalists continued to be targets of the ruling regime. [[Ayman Mohyeldin]], an ''Al Jazeera English'' journalist, was arrested by soldiers in Tahrir Square, and held for 9 hours.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/video/middleeast/2011/02/201127160284430.html |title=Ayman Mohyeldin on his detention |work=Al Jazeera English |date=7 February 2011 |accessdate=7 February 2011}}</ref>
Journalists continued to be targets of the ruling regime. [[Ayman Mohyeldin]], an ''Al Jazeera English'' journalist, was arrested by soldiers in Tahrir Square, and held for 9 hours.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/video/middleeast/2011/02/201127160284430.html |title=Ayman Mohyeldin on his detention |work=Al Jazeera English |date=7 February 2011 |accessdate=7 February 2011}}</ref>
â
Banks temporarily reopened throughout the country amidst long queues,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/06/us-egypt-banks-idUSTRE7150EZ20110206 |title=Customers queue at Egypt banks after protests |publisher=Reuters |date=6 February 2011 |accessdate=6 February 2011}}</ref> and people rushed to buy US dollars.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/egypt-pound-down-less-feared-central-bank-supports |title=Egypt pound down less than feared, central bank supports |work=Al-Masry Al-Youm |date=6 February 2011 |accessdate=6 February 2011}}</ref>
+
Banks temporarily reopened throughout the country amidst long queues,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/06/us-egypt-banks-idUSTRE7150EZ20110206 |title=Customers queue at Egypt banks after protests |publisher=Reuters |date=6 February 2011 |accessdate=6 February 2011}}</ref> and people rushed to buy US dollars.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/egypt-pound-down-less-feared-central-bank-supports |title=Egypt pound down less than feared, central bank supports |work=Al-Masry Al-Youm |date=6 February 2011 |accessdate=6 February 2011}}</ref> The Egyptian stock exchange stayed closed for an eighth day, a stock exchange official told Reuters.
There were also negotiations between Vice President [[Omar Suleiman]] and members from the opposition, including {{link-interwiki|en=Mohammed Morsi|lang=ar|lang_title=ÙØ­ÙØ¯ ÙØ±Ø³Ù}} and [[El-Sayyid el-Badawi]]. The Muslim Brotherhood said it was taking part in a dialogue with the government.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12307698 |title=BBC News - Egypt unrest |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2011-02-06}}</ref> Suleiman agreed to a plan to set up a committee of judiciary and political figures to study constitutional reforms. Results of the committee are due by early March.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110206/D9L7B7IO0.html |title=Egypt's regime makes new concessions to opposition |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-06}}</ref> [[Naguib Sawiris]], who was also involved in the talks, said that "big progress" had been made.<Ref>http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-07/egyptian-credit-risk-falling-to-lowest-since-protests-started.html</ref>
There were also negotiations between Vice President [[Omar Suleiman]] and members from the opposition, including {{link-interwiki|en=Mohammed Morsi|lang=ar|lang_title=ÙØ­ÙØ¯ ÙØ±Ø³Ù}} and [[El-Sayyid el-Badawi]]. The Muslim Brotherhood said it was taking part in a dialogue with the government.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12307698 |title=BBC News - Egypt unrest |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2011-02-06}}</ref> Suleiman agreed to a plan to set up a committee of judiciary and political figures to study constitutional reforms. Results of the committee are due by early March.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110206/D9L7B7IO0.html |title=Egypt's regime makes new concessions to opposition |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-06}}</ref> [[Naguib Sawiris]], who was also involved in the talks, said that "big progress" had been made.<Ref>http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-07/egyptian-credit-risk-falling-to-lowest-since-protests-started.html</ref>
